canonical_explanation.text:
Genetics is the branch of biology that deals with the study of heredity and variation. Gregor Mendel, the father of genetics, conducted hybridisation experiments on garden pea (Pisum sativum) and formulated three laws of inheritance. The law of dominance states that when two organisms differing in a pair of contrasting characters are crossed, only one form (dominant) appears in the F1 generation while the other (recessive) remains hidden. The law of segregation (purity of gametes) states that alleles of a gene separate during gamete formation so that each gamete receives only one allele. The law of independent assortment states that alleles of different genes assort independently during gamete formation, provided the genes are on different chromosomes. A monohybrid cross involves one character and gives a 3:1 phenotypic ratio in F2; a dihybrid cross involves two characters and gives a 9:3:3:1 ratio in F2. A test cross is used to determine the genotype of a dominant phenotype individual by crossing it with a homozygous recessive.

Sometimes Mendelian ratios are modified due to phenomena such as incomplete dominance (e.g., pink flower in snapdragon, 1:2:1 ratio), codominance (e.g., ABO blood groups where both alleles express equally), multiple alleles (e.g., ABO blood group governed by three alleles IA, IB, and i), and pleiotropy (e.g., sickle cell anaemia where a single gene affects multiple traits). Sex determination follows the XX-XY mechanism in humans and Drosophila, while birds follow the ZW-ZZ system. Sex-linked traits are controlled by genes located on sex chromosomes; examples include colour blindness and haemophilia, which are X-linked recessive disorders and more common in males. Chromosomal disorders arise from errors in cell division: aneuploidy includes conditions like Down syndrome (trisomy 21), Turner syndrome (45, XO), and Klinefelter syndrome (47, XXY). Pedigree analysis is a method to trace the inheritance pattern of a trait through successive generations using standard symbols.
rules: Mendel's law of dominance: in a heterozygote, the dominant allele masks the recessive allele
Law of segregation: alleles separate during gamete formation so each gamete carries only one allele of each gene
Law of independent assortment: genes on different chromosomes assort independently during gamete formation
Monohybrid cross F2 ratio is 3:1 (phenotypic) and 1:2:1 (genotypic); dihybrid cross F2 ratio is 9:3:3:1
Test cross: crossing a dominant phenotype individual with homozygous recessive to determine its genotype
Incomplete dominance gives a 1:2:1 phenotypic ratio in F2 (e.g., snapdragon flower colour)
Codominance: both alleles express equally in the heterozygote (e.g., AB blood group)
ABO blood groups are governed by three alleles (IA, IB, i) — an example of multiple allelism
Pleiotropy: a single gene affects multiple phenotypic traits (e.g., sickle cell anaemia gene affects haemoglobin shape and multiple organs)
Sex determination in humans follows XX-XY system; in birds it follows ZW-ZZ system
X-linked recessive traits like colour blindness and haemophilia are more common in males as they have only one X chromosome
Down syndrome: trisomy 21 (47 chromosomes); Turner syndrome: 45, XO (monosomy); Klinefelter syndrome: 47, XXY

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct phenotypic ratio of a monohybrid cross in the F2 generation?
questions.explanation_correct: A monohybrid cross in the F2 generation gives a phenotypic ratio of 3 dominant : 1 recessive. This was demonstrated by Mendel in his experiments with garden pea.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1:2:1 is the genotypic ratio of a monohybrid cross (not phenotypic). 9:3:3:1 is the phenotypic ratio of a dihybrid cross. 1:1 is the ratio obtained in a test cross with a heterozygous individual.

questions.question_text: Mendel's law of segregation is also known as:
questions.explanation_correct: Mendel's law of segregation is also called the law of purity of gametes because the two alleles of a gene separate during gamete formation, and each gamete receives only one pure allele.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Law of dominance explains why only one trait appears in F1. Law of independent assortment deals with inheritance of two or more genes simultaneously. Law of linkage was proposed by Morgan, not Mendel.

questions.question_text: Mendel selected garden pea (Pisum sativum) for his experiments because:

options.text: It has a long generation time
It has many contrasting characters and is naturally self-pollinating

questions.explanation_correct: Mendel chose garden pea because it has several pairs of contrasting characters, is naturally self-pollinating (ensuring pure lines), has a short generation time, and produces a large number of seeds for statistical analysis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pea is predominantly self-pollinating, not cross-pollinating. It has a short generation time (one generation per season), which was advantageous. It produces many seeds per cross, allowing meaningful ratios.

questions.question_text: A test cross is performed between:

options.text: An individual with dominant phenotype and a homozygous recessive individual

questions.explanation_correct: A test cross involves crossing an individual showing the dominant phenotype (unknown genotype) with a homozygous recessive individual. If the offspring are all dominant, the individual is homozygous dominant; if the ratio is 1:1, the individual is heterozygous.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A cross between two heterozygous individuals is a simple monohybrid cross giving a 3:1 ratio. The purpose of a test cross is specifically to determine the genotype of a dominant-phenotype individual using a homozygous recessive tester.

questions.question_text: In a dihybrid cross between two heterozygous parents (RrYy × RrYy), the proportion of offspring that are homozygous for both recessive traits (rryy) in the F2 generation is:
questions.explanation_correct: In a dihybrid cross (RrYy × RrYy), the F2 phenotypic ratio is 9:3:3:1. The double homozygous recessive (rryy) constitutes 1 out of 16, i.e., 1/16 of the total offspring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 9/16 represents the proportion showing both dominant traits. 3/16 represents offspring dominant for one trait and recessive for the other. 1/4 would be the ratio expected in a monohybrid test cross, not a dihybrid F2.

questions.question_text: A tall pea plant (Tt) is crossed with a dwarf pea plant (tt). What percentage of the offspring are expected to be dwarf?
questions.explanation_correct: When a heterozygous tall plant (Tt) is crossed with a homozygous recessive dwarf plant (tt), the offspring are 50% Tt (tall) and 50% tt (dwarf). This is a test cross and gives a 1:1 ratio.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 25% would result in a monohybrid cross (Tt × Tt) for the recessive phenotype. 75% would be the dominant phenotype proportion from Tt × Tt. 100% dwarf would occur only if both parents were tt.

questions.question_text: In which of the following crosses will the law of independent assortment NOT hold true?

options.text: Genes located on the same chromosome and closely linked

questions.explanation_correct: The law of independent assortment applies only to genes located on different chromosomes. Genes that are closely linked on the same chromosome tend to be inherited together and do not assort independently.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Genes on different chromosomes segregate independently as per Mendel's law. Complete dominance and having two alleles do not affect independent assortment. The key factor is chromosomal location.

questions.question_text: A plant heterozygous for two independently assorting genes (AaBb) is selfed. What fraction of the progeny will be heterozygous for both genes?
questions.explanation_correct: For each gene, the probability of heterozygosity (Aa or Bb) from a monohybrid cross is 2/4 = 1/2. Since the genes assort independently, the probability of being heterozygous for both = 1/2 × 1/2 = 1/4 = 4/16.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1/16 is the probability of being homozygous recessive for both traits. 9/16 is the proportion showing both dominant phenotypes. 2/16 does not correspond to any standard Mendelian fraction for this cross.

questions.question_text: In Mendel's experiment, when a tall heterozygous (Tt) plant was self-pollinated, the F2 generation had 800 plants. The expected number of plants that are homozygous tall (TT) is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: In a monohybrid cross Tt × Tt, the genotypic ratio is 1 TT : 2 Tt : 1 tt. The proportion of homozygous tall (TT) is 1/4. Therefore, expected number = 1/4 × 800 = 200 plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 400 would be the number of heterozygous (Tt) plants. 600 would be the total tall plants (TT + Tt). 100 would be an incorrect calculation not corresponding to any expected ratio.

questions.question_text: Mendel's work was rediscovered independently by three scientists in the year 1900. They were:
questions.explanation_correct: Mendel's work, published in 1866, remained unrecognised until 1900 when it was independently rediscovered by Hugo de Vries (Holland), Carl Correns (Germany), and Erich von Tschermak (Austria).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bateson, Punnett, and Morgan made important contributions to genetics but did not rediscover Mendel's work. Watson, Crick, and Wilkins discovered the structure of DNA. Sutton and Boveri proposed the chromosomal theory of inheritance.

questions.question_text: In snapdragon (Antirrhinum), a cross between red-flowered (RR) and white-flowered (rr) plants produces pink-flowered (Rr) offspring. This is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: In incomplete dominance, the F1 hybrid shows an intermediate phenotype between the two parental phenotypes. In snapdragon, heterozygous plants (Rr) show pink flowers — intermediate between red (RR) and white (rr).
questions.explanation_incorrect: In complete dominance, the heterozygote looks like the dominant parent. In codominance, both alleles express equally (not an intermediate). Epistasis involves one gene masking the expression of another gene.

questions.question_text: ABO blood grouping in humans is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: ABO blood group is controlled by gene I, which has three alleles — IA, IB, and i. This is multiple allelism. When IA and IB are present together, both are expressed equally, producing AB blood group — this is codominance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Incomplete dominance produces an intermediate phenotype, which is not seen in ABO blood groups. Polygenic inheritance involves many genes controlling a single trait (e.g., skin colour). Epistasis involves interaction between different genes.

questions.question_text: Sickle cell anaemia is caused by substitution of which amino acid in the beta-globin chain of haemoglobin?

options.text: Glutamic acid is replaced by alanine
Glutamic acid is replaced by valine
Valine is replaced by glutamic acid

questions.explanation_correct: In sickle cell anaemia, a point mutation in the beta-globin gene causes the substitution of glutamic acid (at the 6th position) by valine. This changes the shape of haemoglobin molecules, causing RBCs to become sickle-shaped under low oxygen conditions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The substitution is specifically glutamic acid to valine, not to alanine. The reverse (valine to glutamic acid) would be incorrect as well. This single amino acid change has pleiotropic effects on multiple organ systems.

questions.question_text: A person with blood group AB can receive blood from:

options.text: All blood groups (A, B, AB, and O)

questions.explanation_correct: A person with blood group AB has both A and B antigens on RBCs and no anti-A or anti-B antibodies in the plasma. Therefore, AB is the universal recipient and can receive blood from all groups (A, B, AB, and O).
questions.explanation_incorrect: AB individuals do not produce anti-A or anti-B antibodies, so they can accept blood from all groups without agglutination. They are not restricted to any single blood group donor.

questions.question_text: In a cross between red-flowered (RR) and white-flowered (rr) snapdragons showing incomplete dominance, what will be the phenotypic ratio in the F2 generation?
questions.explanation_correct: In incomplete dominance, the F1 (Rr) is pink. When F1 plants are selfed (Rr × Rr), the F2 generation shows a phenotypic ratio of 1 red (RR) : 2 pink (Rr) : 1 white (rr). Here, the phenotypic and genotypic ratios are the same.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A 3:1 ratio is seen in complete dominance, not incomplete dominance. All pink would be the F1 generation only. The key difference is that in incomplete dominance, the heterozygote has a distinct phenotype.

questions.question_text: Parents with blood groups A (IAi) and B (IBi) can have children with which of the following blood groups?
questions.explanation_correct: Cross IAi × IBi produces offspring with genotypes: IAIB (AB), IAi (A), IBi (B), and ii (O). Therefore, all four blood groups are possible in the children of these parents.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since both parents are heterozygous carriers of the recessive i allele, there is a 1/4 chance of producing an O (ii) child. Hence, all four blood groups are possible, not just A, B, or AB.

questions.question_text: Sickle cell anaemia is an example of pleiotropy because:

options.text: It is controlled by multiple genes
A single gene mutation affects multiple phenotypic expressions

questions.explanation_correct: Pleiotropy is the phenomenon where a single gene controls or affects multiple phenotypic traits. In sickle cell anaemia, the mutant HbS gene not only causes defective haemoglobin but also leads to anaemia, organ damage, pain crises, and spleen enlargement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sickle cell anaemia is controlled by a single gene (not multiple genes — that would be polygenic). It shows codominance at the molecular level (HbA and HbS), not incomplete dominance. It is an autosomal disorder, not sex-linked.

questions.question_text: Which of the following crosses will produce offspring with blood group O?
questions.explanation_correct: Blood group O has genotype ii. For an O child, both parents must carry at least one i allele. In the cross IAi × IBi, one possible offspring genotype is ii (blood group O), with a probability of 1/4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: IAIA × IBIB can only produce IAIB (AB) children. IAIB × IAIA can produce IAIA or IAIB — no O. IAIB × IBIB can produce IAIB or IBIB — no O. Only heterozygous parents carrying the i allele can produce O offspring.

questions.question_text: In a population, multiple alleles can be found for a gene, but a diploid individual can possess:

options.text: All the alleles present in the population

questions.explanation_correct: Although multiple alleles may exist in a population (e.g., three alleles IA, IB, i for ABO blood groups), a diploid individual has only two copies of each gene (one from each parent) and can carry a maximum of any two of those alleles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A diploid organism carries two alleles per gene (one on each homologous chromosome), not just one. An individual cannot carry all alleles of a population — only two at a time.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about codominance is correct?

options.text: The F1 hybrid shows an intermediate phenotype
Both alleles express themselves equally and independently in the heterozygote
One allele completely masks the other
The recessive allele is expressed in the F2 generation only

questions.explanation_correct: In codominance, both alleles of a gene are equally expressed in the heterozygous condition. For example, in blood group AB (genotype IAIB), both A and B antigens are produced on the surface of RBCs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An intermediate phenotype is characteristic of incomplete dominance, not codominance. In codominance, neither allele masks the other — both are fully expressed. The recessive allele concept does not apply in codominance.

questions.question_text: In humans, the sex of the child is determined by:
questions.explanation_correct: In humans, females are XX and males are XY. All eggs carry an X chromosome. Sperms carry either X or Y. If an X-bearing sperm fertilises the egg, the child is female (XX); if a Y-bearing sperm fertilises the egg, the child is male (XY). Hence, the father's sperm determines the sex.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mother always contributes an X chromosome, so her egg does not determine sex. Environmental factors do not determine sex in humans. Autosomes are the same in males and females (22 pairs).

questions.question_text: Colour blindness is a sex-linked recessive trait in humans. A colour-blind man marries a normal-vision woman (not a carrier). What proportion of their sons will be colour blind?
questions.explanation_correct: The colour-blind father (XcY) passes his Xc to all daughters and Y to all sons. The mother (XCXC) passes one XC to each child. All sons receive XC from mother and Y from father, making them XCY (normal vision). None of the sons will be colour blind.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sons inherit their X chromosome from the mother, not the father. Since the mother is homozygous normal (XCXC), all sons will have normal vision. The colour-blind allele from the father goes only to daughters (who become carriers).

questions.question_text: In birds, sex determination follows the:

options.text: XX-XY system with males being heterogametic
ZW-ZZ system with females being heterogametic

questions.explanation_correct: In birds, sex determination follows the ZW-ZZ system. Females are heterogametic (ZW) and produce two types of gametes (Z and W), while males are homogametic (ZZ). This is the reverse of the human XX-XY system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: XX-XY system with heterogametic males is found in humans and Drosophila. XX-XO system is found in grasshoppers. Haplodiploidy is found in honey bees where unfertilised eggs develop into males.

questions.question_text: Haemophilia is a sex-linked recessive disorder that is more common in males because:

options.text: Males have only one X chromosome and the Y does not carry the gene for haemophilia
The gene is located on the Y chromosome

questions.explanation_correct: Haemophilia is X-linked recessive. Males (XY) have only one X chromosome, so a single recessive allele on their X will express the disorder. Females need two copies of the recessive allele (one on each X) to be affected, making it much rarer in females.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Males have one X chromosome, not two. The haemophilia gene is on the X chromosome, not the Y. Males are more susceptible precisely because they lack a second X to mask the defective allele.

questions.question_text: A carrier woman for haemophilia (XHXh) marries a normal man (XHY). What is the probability of their children being haemophilic?
questions.explanation_correct: Cross: XHXh × XHY → XHXH (normal female), XHXh (carrier female), XHY (normal male), XhY (haemophilic male). Only XhY sons are affected = 1 out of 4 children = 25% of all children. Among sons specifically, 50% will be haemophilic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 50% of all children is incorrect — only 25% (one out of four) will be haemophilic. 50% of sons will be affected, but the question asks about all children. Not all sons will be affected; only those inheriting Xh from the mother.

questions.question_text: A colour-blind woman (XcXc) marries a man with normal vision (XCY). What will be the phenotype of their daughters?

options.text: All daughters will be colour blind
All daughters will be carriers with normal vision
Half daughters colour blind, half normal
All daughters will have normal vision (not carriers)

questions.explanation_correct: The mother (XcXc) passes Xc to all children. The father (XCY) passes XC to all daughters. So all daughters will be XCXc — carriers with normal vision, since the normal allele (XC) is dominant over the colour-blind allele (Xc).
questions.explanation_incorrect: All daughters inherit XC from the father, so they will have normal vision (XC is dominant). They are carriers (XCXc), not homozygous normal. No daughter will be colour blind since they all get one normal X from the father.

questions.question_text: In honey bees, males (drones) develop from unfertilised eggs. This type of sex determination is called:
questions.explanation_correct: In honey bees, sex determination is based on the number of chromosome sets. Females (queen and workers) develop from fertilised eggs and are diploid (2n = 32). Males (drones) develop from unfertilised eggs by parthenogenesis and are haploid (n = 16). This system is called haplodiploidy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: XX-XY is found in humans and Drosophila. ZW-ZZ is found in birds and some reptiles. XX-XO is found in grasshoppers. Haplodiploidy is unique to organisms like bees, wasps, and ants.

questions.question_text: A normal-visioned woman, whose father was colour blind, marries a normal-visioned man. The probability that their son will be colour blind is:
questions.explanation_correct: The woman's father was colour blind (XcY), so she must have received one Xc from him. Since she has normal vision, her genotype is XCXc (carrier). Her husband is XCY. Cross: XCXc × XCY → sons are XCY or XcY. So 50% of sons will be colour blind.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 0% is wrong because the mother is a carrier. 25% would be the percentage among all children, not specifically sons. 100% is wrong because only the sons receiving Xc from the mother will be colour blind.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about sex-linked inheritance is INCORRECT?

options.text: Father passes his X chromosome to all daughters
Mother passes one X chromosome to both sons and daughters
Father passes his Y chromosome to all sons
Father passes his X chromosome to all sons

questions.explanation_correct: The father (XY) passes his X chromosome to all daughters and Y chromosome to all sons. He does NOT pass his X chromosome to sons. Therefore, the statement 'Father passes his X chromosome to all sons' is incorrect.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is true that the father passes X to all daughters and Y to all sons. The mother passes one of her two X chromosomes to each child (son or daughter). These are all correct statements about sex-linked inheritance.

questions.question_text: In Drosophila, sex is determined by:

options.text: The ratio of number of X chromosomes to the number of sets of autosomes
The presence or absence of the Y chromosome

questions.explanation_correct: In Drosophila, sex is determined by the genic balance theory — the ratio of X chromosomes to autosome sets (X:A ratio). If X:A = 1, the fly is female; if X:A = 0.5, it is male. The Y chromosome does not determine sex in Drosophila (unlike in humans).
questions.explanation_incorrect: In humans, the Y chromosome (specifically the SRY gene) determines maleness, but this is not the case in Drosophila. ZW-ZZ is for birds. Haplodiploidy is for honey bees.

questions.question_text: Down syndrome in humans is caused by:
questions.explanation_correct: Down syndrome is caused by trisomy of chromosome 21, i.e., the individual has three copies of chromosome 21 instead of the normal two. The total chromosome number is 47 (2n + 1). It is the most common autosomal aneuploidy in humans.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Monosomy of chromosome 21 is not a recognised syndrome. Trisomy 18 causes Edwards syndrome. Deletion in chromosome 5 causes Cri-du-chat syndrome. Down syndrome is specifically trisomy 21.

questions.question_text: Turner syndrome is characterised by the chromosomal constitution:
questions.explanation_correct: Turner syndrome occurs in females with the chromosomal constitution 45, XO (44 autosomes + one X chromosome). The individual is phenotypically female but is sterile, short-statured, and lacks secondary sexual characters.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 44 + XXY (47, XXY) is Klinefelter syndrome. 44 + XXX is super female (triple X syndrome). 44 + XYY is XYY syndrome. Turner syndrome specifically involves monosomy of the X chromosome.

questions.question_text: Klinefelter syndrome is characterised by which of the following?
questions.explanation_correct: Klinefelter syndrome occurs in males with the chromosomal constitution 47, XXY (44 autosomes + XXY). Affected individuals are phenotypically male but show gynaecomastia (breast development), are tall, and are usually sterile.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 45, XO is Turner syndrome (female). 47, XXX is triple X syndrome (female). Klinefelter syndrome specifically involves an extra X chromosome in males, giving the XXY constitution.

questions.question_text: In a pedigree chart, a solid/filled symbol represents:
questions.explanation_correct: In pedigree analysis, filled (solid/shaded) symbols represent individuals who are affected by the trait or disorder being studied. Unfilled (open) symbols represent unaffected individuals. Circles represent females and squares represent males.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Open/unfilled symbols represent unaffected individuals. Carriers are usually shown as half-filled symbols. A diagonal line through the symbol typically indicates a deceased individual.

questions.question_text: Non-disjunction of chromosomes during meiosis can lead to:
questions.explanation_correct: Non-disjunction is the failure of homologous chromosomes or sister chromatids to separate during meiosis. This leads to gametes with an abnormal number of chromosomes — one gamete has an extra chromosome and the other has one fewer. This results in aneuploidy (e.g., trisomy or monosomy) in the offspring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Inversion and translocation are structural chromosomal aberrations, not numerical. Point mutations involve changes in a single nucleotide. Non-disjunction specifically causes numerical changes (aneuploidy).

questions.question_text: A couple has a child with Down syndrome. The most probable cause is:

options.text: Deletion in one of the autosomes
Non-disjunction of chromosome 21 during gamete formation in one of the parents

questions.explanation_correct: Down syndrome is most commonly caused by non-disjunction of chromosome 21 during meiosis in one of the parents (usually the mother). This results in a gamete with two copies of chromosome 21, leading to trisomy 21 in the offspring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Deletion of an autosome would cause a different set of abnormalities. Translocation between sex chromosomes does not cause Down syndrome. Gene mutations cause single-gene disorders, not chromosomal disorders like Down syndrome.

questions.question_text: In a pedigree, a trait appears in every generation and affected fathers pass the trait to all daughters but not to sons. This pattern suggests:
questions.explanation_correct: In X-linked dominant inheritance, an affected father (XAY) passes the affected X chromosome to all his daughters (who will all be affected) and the Y to all his sons (who will be unaffected from this parent). The trait appears in every generation as it is dominant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In autosomal dominant inheritance, affected fathers pass the trait to approximately half of all children, regardless of sex. In autosomal recessive, both parents must be carriers. In X-linked recessive, carrier mothers pass the trait to sons.

questions.question_text: An individual with Turner syndrome has how many Barr bodies in their cells?
questions.explanation_correct: A Barr body is formed by the inactivation of one X chromosome. The number of Barr bodies = total X chromosomes − 1. Turner syndrome individuals have only one X chromosome (XO), so Barr bodies = 1 − 1 = 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Normal females (XX) have 1 Barr body. Klinefelter syndrome males (XXY) have 1 Barr body. Triple X females (XXX) have 2 Barr bodies. Turner syndrome (XO) individuals have 0 Barr bodies.

questions.question_text: Which of the following chromosomal disorders is correctly matched with its chromosomal constitution?
questions.explanation_correct: Klinefelter syndrome has the chromosomal constitution 44 + XXY (total 47 chromosomes). Down syndrome is trisomy 21 (45 + XX or XY = 47 chromosomes). Turner syndrome is 44 + XO (total 45 chromosomes).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Down syndrome involves trisomy of autosome 21, not a sex chromosome anomaly. Turner syndrome is 44 + XO, not XXY. The correct matches are: Down = trisomy 21, Turner = 45,XO, Klinefelter = 47,XXY.

questions.question_text: A pedigree shows that two normal parents have an affected son. The trait does not appear in every generation. The most likely mode of inheritance is:
questions.explanation_correct: When both parents are unaffected but produce an affected child, it indicates a recessive pattern. Since the son is affected and both parents are carriers, the trait is autosomal recessive. The trait may skip generations, appearing only when two carriers mate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Autosomal dominant traits appear in every generation — at least one parent must be affected. X-linked dominant also requires an affected parent. Y-linked traits pass only from father to son and would require an affected father.

questions.question_text: Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an inborn error of metabolism caused by deficiency of the enzyme:
questions.explanation_correct: Phenylketonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, which converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. Accumulation of phenylalanine and its derivatives causes intellectual disability.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tyrosinase deficiency causes albinism. Lactase deficiency causes lactose intolerance. Hexosaminidase deficiency causes Tay-Sachs disease. PKU is specifically caused by phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency.

questions.question_text: If a cross between a yellow round seeded plant (YyRr) and a green wrinkled seeded plant (yyrr) is performed, the number of different phenotypes expected in the offspring is:
questions.explanation_correct: This is a dihybrid test cross (YyRr × yyrr). The offspring will be: YyRr (yellow round), Yyrr (yellow wrinkled), yyRr (green round), yyrr (green wrinkled). There are 4 phenotypes in a 1:1:1:1 ratio.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A dihybrid test cross gives 4 phenotypic classes, not 2 or 8 or 16. The ratio 1:1:1:1 indicates four equal phenotypic categories.

questions.question_text: The chromosomal theory of inheritance was proposed by:
questions.explanation_correct: The chromosomal theory of inheritance was proposed independently by Walter Sutton and Theodor Boveri in 1902. They stated that genes (Mendelian factors) are located on chromosomes and chromosomes are the vehicles of heredity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mendel proposed the laws of inheritance but did not link them to chromosomes. Watson and Crick elucidated DNA structure. Morgan provided experimental evidence for the chromosomal theory using Drosophila.

questions.question_text: In a family, the father has blood group A (homozygous IAIA) and the mother has blood group B (homozygous IBIB). What blood group(s) can be expected in their children?

options.text: All children will have blood group AB
All children will have blood group O

questions.explanation_correct: Cross: IAIA × IBIB → all offspring will be IAIB. Since IA and IB are codominant, all children will express both A and B antigens and have blood group AB.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When both parents are homozygous (IAIA and IBIB), all children receive one IA and one IB allele. There is no possibility of A, B, or O blood groups separately. All children will be AB.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of an autosomal disorder?
questions.explanation_correct: Sickle cell anaemia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the beta-globin gene located on chromosome 11 (an autosome). Colour blindness, haemophilia, and Duchenne muscular dystrophy are all X-linked disorders.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Colour blindness, haemophilia, and Duchenne muscular dystrophy are sex-linked (X-linked) recessive disorders, not autosomal. Sickle cell anaemia is autosomal because the gene is on chromosome 11.

questions.question_text: The condition in which an organism has an extra chromosome (2n + 1) is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Trisomy is the condition where an organism has one extra chromosome (2n + 1). It results from non-disjunction during cell division. Down syndrome (trisomy 21) is a well-known example of trisomy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Polyploidy is having more than two complete sets of chromosomes. Monosomy is having one chromosome less (2n − 1). Nullisomy is having two chromosomes less (2n − 2). Trisomy specifically means 2n + 1.

questions.question_text: A person with genotype IAIB has blood group AB. This is because IA and IB alleles are:

options.text: Codominant, each producing its own antigen

questions.explanation_correct: In blood group AB (genotype IAIB), both alleles IA and IB are expressed equally and independently. IA produces antigen A and IB produces antigen B on the surface of RBCs. This is a classic example of codominance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Neither allele is recessive to the other in this case. Incomplete dominance would produce a blended intermediate phenotype. Epistasis involves one gene masking another gene entirely. Codominance means both alleles express fully.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic feature of Mendel's experimental plant, Pisum sativum?

options.text: Production of large number of seeds

questions.explanation_correct: Pisum sativum is predominantly self-pollinating, not naturally cross-pollinating. Self-pollination was advantageous for Mendel because it helped maintain pure lines. Cross-pollination could be easily performed artificially when needed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Short generation time, availability of several contrasting characters (7 pairs), and large number of seeds were all actual advantages that made pea a suitable experimental organism for Mendel.

questions.question_text: Which of the following conditions is possible for a woman to be haemophilic?

options.text: Her father is haemophilic and her mother is a carrier
Her father is normal and her mother is haemophilic
Both parents are normal and non-carriers
Her father is haemophilic and her mother is normal (non-carrier)

questions.explanation_correct: For a woman to be haemophilic (XhXh), she must inherit the recessive allele from both parents. Her father must be haemophilic (XhY) to pass Xh, and her mother must be at least a carrier (XHXh) to pass Xh. The cross XHXh × XhY gives 1/4 chance of XhXh (haemophilic daughter).
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the mother is haemophilic (XhXh) and father is normal (XHY), daughters will be carriers (XHXh), not haemophilic. If both parents are non-carriers, no haemophilic offspring can be born. The father must be haemophilic and the mother must be at least a carrier.

questions.question_text: Which of the following features is seen in individuals with Down syndrome?

options.text: Short stature, broad palm with single palmar crease, and intellectual disability

questions.explanation_correct: Down syndrome (trisomy 21) is characterised by short stature, a broad flat face, a characteristic single transverse palmar crease (simian crease), intellectual disability, and congenital heart defects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tall stature and long limbs are not features of Down syndrome. Underdeveloped gonads and gynaecomastia are features of Klinefelter syndrome (47, XXY). Webbed neck and rudimentary ovaries are features of Turner syndrome (45, XO).
